c_OH88z0JdQHd_tZtWhcUw.text: Love this small, quirky place. Hidden gem, the fisherman's stew is to die for! Highly recommend for any occasion.

exAIOE2OXKeDJJHQMGv1Qg.text: Fantastic cozy & artistic & foreign ambiance. Good food. Great decor.  (For the record, I tried my first liver here - which I thought would be pate, but was not - to my hidden horror. I ate a bite - in front of my clients & colleagues - for good measure [and to hide my naievete], but they eventually noticed I was not eating it. I politely, humbly explained my mistake, and they respected me for trying something new. Of course my client then told me about blood tofu, which was a bit shocking, but I firmly believe in expanding one's own mind and perceptions of the world and all its cultures, so I appreciated his sharing. Adding this experience to that of eating bone marrow here at Pulpo in D.C.)

Jylq9f_4w17QeUgAjP0Q4A.text: Wow!  We were looking forward to this for our anniversary, and we weren't disappointed!  We splurged with three starters:  grilled sardines, octopus, and pheasant terrine.  Each was lovelier than the next.  The terrine was particularly delicious, served with some sort of artisanal mustard and pickled onions on the side, and some nicely grilled bread.  The octopus was perfectly cooked, not rubbery at all, but buttery, nicely seasoned and presented.  The sardines were grill-hot with an ever so slightly charred and crispy skin, and the accompanying vegetables were barely warm, which actually made for a nice contrast.  Main courses:  I had the shellfish stew from the menu.  All of the various seafood was perfectly cooked.  The broth could have had a bit more heat for my taste, but still: lovely.  The husband had one of the specials: cassoulet with venison osso buco. Heavenly, especially on a winter evening.  Gorgeous venison shanks and dome nicely roasted vegetables.  Another splurge: dessert.  We had the chocolate terrine and the key lime creme brulee, both of which were understated and luxurious.  Not fans of big, vulgar desserts, so these were right up our alley--rich, flavorful, just a nice sweet little end to a perfect meal.  Service was especially nice and attentive, but never intrusive.  Loved the shabby chic decor and the oddly shaped dining room.  Must be lovely in the summer with doors open in this quiet corner of Shadyside.  We'll definitely return to find out!

2fjMfgz2qdY1nldprxjnvg.text: I have been to this restaurant many times in the past and have typically had good food and decent service. Last night we were sorely disappointed in the food, service and venue. We reserved a party of 9 two weeks ago for a friend's birthday. When we arrived (to a virtually empty restaurant) the table they had for us was crammed against the wall and the chairs were so tight together that we couldn't move.  We asked to be moved and they refused.  Then we order food and we were told that the fish had bones. Well it was ALL bones. At $44 a plate they could have filleted the damn fish.     After a very mediocre dinner one of us (seated next to me) ordered tea.  The waitress brought the oversized tea box to the table and knocked me in the eye with it. Yes I'm sore and have a terrible headache. Luckily I still have my eye. Not only did they not offer to comp my dinner but the owner never even came over to see if I was ok. VERY BAD FORM TONY.   We will probably not be back.

j9O4q4jNhP0BL3aGUefkEA.text: What a gem of a place in Shadyside.  It s places like this that makes me miss living there.  Food was outstanding!  Because it was our first time, we wanted to do a little bit of this and that.  2 appetizers, Becky s salad and the special of the eve:  smoked salmon on crostini with creme fresh, a clam dish, forgot name, with the best tomatoe-white wine, I could have drunk from the bowl, broth; Becky s salad (the lemon dressing was out of this world delicious--again, could have drunk it, good).  I m usually not fan of walnut in my salad, but the crumbled goat cheese made me forget about my dislike of it, that I ate it happily.  Good pairing.  The special of the night, we opted for sharing the lamb shank with reduced red wine sauce and simple veggies.  Small veggie selection by american standards--half russet potato, slither of zucchini, and a stem of green onion, but the star afterall was the lamb, and it was meduim perfect, just as I ordered!   "Would you care for some dessert?", Ramon, our waiter (he was fabulous!) asked.  And so round 3 begins.  Coffee, a chocolate mousse with whip cream, beauty and...  their version of creme brulee.  I thought it had a hint of peanut butter, but not sure.  Regardless it was  so, so divine. This place was busy but we did not feel rushed, unlike most places.  The service was great, the atmoshphere quaint; it s definitely a neighbourhood cafe-- alot of repeat clientele, from what I gathered.  We shall return. Finally, on an end note. Cafe Zinho is BYOB, so bring your favourite bottle or magnum of vino.  And they only take cash or personal check, but they do have an ATM.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Zinho - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Smoked salmon on crostini,  with creme fresh
Photo of Cafe Zinho - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Clams swimming in a tomato and white wine sauce.  The sauce is good enough to drink!

YNQMNjf2N-226BHMpztlMQ.text: The food here is really amazing. We ordered stuffed cornbread and vegetable soup as appetizers. For entree we had roasted duck and pork loin. They both taste really Portugal with a hint of sweetness. The downside of this restaurant is that they ONLY accept cash.

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Zinho - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Amazing pork loin! The quality of the pork is really good!
Photo of Cafe Zinho - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Duck. Very Portugal. I really like the sauce
Photo of Cafe Zinho - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vegetable soup and the special cornbread stuffed with beef. I love it!

pi_nnmQIBl0QXy8d2wanJg.text: I like the atmosphere, the food and the service. Just is a little small and expensive. But if don't care about the price is very good recommedation. Especially their bread that is free. I love it!!

PKD8z0e3bBKBQyHD5wVf9A.text: Your review helps others learn about great local businesses. My husband and I have been to Cafe Zinho many times, and have always been greeted at the door , and made feel very welcome.  The staff is wonderful, very attentive, and knowledgeable about the menu.  The food is wonderful, and Toni always makes an appearance to check on how we are enjoying our meal.  The fact that you an have such a good meal, bring your own wine to enjoy, and have a little taste of Europe in Shadyside makes it a real gem.  Please don't review this business if you received a freebie for writing this review, or if you're connected in any way to the owner or employees.

97nkMtuBfo8uMqv5CIrIyA.text: Best Mussels!!! They were large and quite tasty.  The starter bread is corn bread and it is absolutely addicting.  My boyfriend and I had dinner on a whim on a weekday and we thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.  The setting is intimate and I enjoyed it.  I only wish we would've brought a bottle of wine since it's BYOB. The service was excellent as well. I have no complaints, even if it is CASH only I think it's worth it.   NOTE: Cash only.  They do have an ATM inside for your convenience. BYOB

DCTJDbQVTbW_uQuwQq0y0Q.text: This restaurant does NOT deserve the 4 Star Rating it has on Yelp...a 5 Star Rating is much more fitting.  Let's break it down:  a perfect cozy location off of Ellsworth, it's BYOB - which is always a bonus, an eclectic & intimate setting (get there early and request window seating), an attentive wait staff that is warm and welcoming...and I haven't EVEN gotten to the meal itself yet!   My husband and I took our 6 year old daughter there and we all had an amazing experience and delicious meal.  My husband's lamb burger melted in his mouth, my lamb chops were tender (medium rare) and juicy with just enough spices, my daughters spinach and cheese ravioli was so yummy she was practically licking her plate (insert appropriate level of parenting/manners ;~) All in all, my 'foody family' gave this 'gem of a Portuguese/Mediterranean restaurant' an ENTHUSIASTIC THUMBS UP!  And, due to our phenomenal dining experience last night, will be making our next dining outing very soon to Cafe Zinho.

E_HeLBjFcBjY_zX9J20vWw.text: This off the beaten path restaurant in Shadyside is a must visit. I went for the first time a few years ago with my husband and then recently a few weeks ago with my girlfriends. Both experiences were different but amazing. The food is really good. Most recently I got a pork loin dish which was served with an amarena cherry sauce. The restaurant is BYOB and overall reasonably priced. We sampled some appetizers for the group dinner and shared a dessert - everyone enjoyed everything!   We did have one run in, I believe with a regular customer, that stopped by and told us we were being too loud. Since he was a regular I was nervous the server would come over and ask us to be more quiet. However, she actually came over to apologize and let us know we weren't doing anything wrong.  The space is a bit small so it can be a little loud when it gets full but I didn't think it was unbearable.   This place is cash only but they do have an ATM.

6_BGQpA8ucr6_pz5o0bQyQ.text: It's been many years since our last visit to Cafe Zinho. It's unchanged and still excellent. It's small, loud, wired, and unique. The food is excellent, service professional, and overall experience great. We had the beet salad, ravioli, and seafood stew. Great. Why have we been away so long?

TKzCZXuVmuyUWVNNm_zf2A.text: Just love the quaint and cozy feel of the restaurant.  Plus it is BYOB.  The staff was very friendly and helpful in describing some of the items on the menu and provided very attentive service.  The staff delivered some corn bread to start that was warm, soft and very good.  We started with the goat cheese stuffed pastry puff with a peach sauce.  Tasty with a light and airy pastry with a nice mild cheese and a wonderful sauce.  Had a hard time deciding what to order with so many items on the menu that sounded so good.  However being a crab cake fan, I decided on the crab cake and was not disappointed.  Two good sized crab cakes that were very tender and with a nice warm crab flavor.  For desert we tried a chocolate truffle, forgot the name, that was just heavenly.

c0hnXIeE6Ky6aN0VdgUF2g.text: Our experience here was wonderful. We walked in and were so warmly greeted. Our service from Kiwi was outstanding. The atmosphere is just so quaint. The food- Delicious! They accommodated my choice of a non dairy sauce on my bass. The prices are high. It is a byob so that helps. I can't wait to go back! I want to give this restaurant 4 stars for the high pricing but I can't. Our night was so enjoyable!

C1K22RrXvWzkpIvJClOaEA.text: Return visit to Cafe Zinho was wonderful.  Starters of gazpacho, summer salad, escargot, and clams were all excellent.  Main courses of pork with cherries, grilled branzino, portabello mushroom ravioli, and duck also all excellent.  Desserts of bread pudding, chocolate mousse and chocolate velvet, topped off a great meal.  Service was attentive and pleasant.  Thanks to Toni and his BOH and FOH staff for a memorable evening.  Memories of Baum Vivant for sure.

64GGXlzWPS7llkKNYuFCog.text: Excellent food and very accommodating staff. A great small restaurant that my wife and I will definitely be going back to.

WNJtHTYXa-Ji-dg4DAZZPw.text: Toni Pais is one of the pioneers of Fine Dining in Pittsburgh. Every meal at Zinho is planned and prepared by Toni. His weekly menus always include a selection of fresh  Fish, Fowl, Meat and Vegan options.   If you enjoy a comfortably small restaurant with genuine attention paid to providing diners a quality dining experience then do yourself a favor and visit Cafe Zinho.  BYOB

djiCEke-Fu8q6gxLD5zLUg.text: We had such a wonderful experience. Food and service were perfect. Definitely get the frog leg app if it's on the menu when you visit too!

7TQmlL8mQ84LlC3RJa4HDg.text: Beets, Bronzino and Brulee! Dinner began with the decadent Goat cheese puff pastry.  The flavors harmonized beautifully and awakened our taste buds for the beet and goat cheese salad. Divine. We then split the roasted duck and the Bronzino entrees. Both were nothing short of fantastic and we finished the evening off with the creme brulee. This no fuss cafe has a chef who blows your mind and an ambiance that melts your heart. One of our favorite restaurants and we never leave unsatisfied. Imagine going to your mom's house, but your mom has a full staff and an extensive menu of exquisite dishes.  Don't hesitate but don't forget to hit the atm first. Cash only!

photos.caption: Photo of Cafe Zinho - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Cafe Zinho - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

gzOsaTgHlgjc4B72MIztDQ.text: I'm gonna update this to a solid 4 after last night's visit.   I still think the whole cash only thing is silly and that they should have a better web presence, but our meal was absolutely delicious.  This time around, I went with the seafood stew.  I was trying to be a little calorie conscious, so I skipped the appetizer round (which my companions all loved).  I couldn't resist a little nibble of the warm bread though.   Yum.     That seafood stew was a winner for sure.   I was expecting it to be small, but it was really ample and filling.  Three each of large scallops, large shrimp, plump mussels, and clams swimming in a yummy tomato broth and topped with a lobster tail.   It was a beautiful and tasty dish that I would absolutely order again.  It was $38 if I remember correctly, which I didn't really mind since the dish was very good and filling.  My only note would be that it was a little awkward to eat with the shells and tails, etc.

hw8YpqrJa1vS7WLOA8As2Q.text: I ordered the crab cakes with the aioli. My daughter got the fish bronzino. Husband got the fillet mignon burger. Everything tasted very good. Service was excellent. Nice Portuguese restaurant. Parking is limited. Get there early. Will go back!

zT2YJPRqZhtXaql_tOHcgA.text: Everything was outstanding!  There were three of us dining and I had tastes of the vegan pea soup and the duck-confit cake with bbq sauce.  My striped bass with a lovely sauce and silvered roasted almonds was delicious!  The bread was delicious and the chocolate mousse was perfect! Everything was wonderful.  Cash or personal check only, ATM on site.  BYOB

8njHGuqm_-Y0kREH3aMwgQ.text: Food was very good. Did not appreciate that when we had just completed our meal the manager came to tell us we needed to leave as they had an 8pm reservation. Our reservation was at 6:30pm. One doesn't expect to be asked to leave right after completing meal when $200 was spent by the 4 of us. As good as the food was, we will not be going back.

ndzrsPTtJsNatAVJjAWL2g.text: Cafe Zinho is a cute little restaurant tucked away on a street corner in Shadyside that serves up Portuguese food. Everything looked great on the menu, but execution was flawed through out our meal. Also, their dishes are not really Portuguese.  For appetizers, we got chicken livers and portuguese bread pudding with mushroom cream sauce. The chicken livers lacked flavor, which is unfortunate because chicken livers on their own are not very tasty. The bread pudding was pretty good though.  Entrees were, on the whole, not impressive. The lamb chops were obviously over cooked (we ordered medium rare, and the insides were almost fully cooked). The duck breast which people raved about online were tough and the sauce was too sweet. The seafood stew lacked flavor. The lamb burger was also overcooked.

Photo of Cafe Zinho - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Lamb chops

1XuAwEralg1zmYnmPXu9lQ.text: I've lived near Cafe Zinho for the longest time and had wanted to try it. I was so glad I did! The place is BYOB so make sure to bring something to enjoy your dinner with! One thing I took issue with was that Cafe Zinho doesn't have any internet presence. While this isn't necessarily a terrible thing, it doesn't allow you to get a good idea of whats on the menu before you visit as their are lots of seasonal specials. It also doesn't allow you to get a good idea of pricing. For the record, appetizers are in the $8-$15 dollar range, entrees are approximately $18-$35, and dessert was about another $10.   As for the food, the Portugese Cornbread that came to our table was outstanding. Our table also ordered a goat cheese pastry appetizer that was fantastic. Our entrees were good but weren't as exemplary. For dessert we got a "chocolate velvet" with cayenne pepper and a berry sauce drizzle. It was a great finish to the meal. However, we were surprised to find, upon getting our checks that Cafe Zinho is cash or check only. They have an ATM on sight but it's something I wish I would have known beforehand.  The atmosphere was intimate and warm, the prices were reasonable, and the food was exceptional. I'd definitely recommend Cafe Zinho to others.

ke613sw-vWCsYI1q-elmnA.text: Chef Tony offers authentic Portuguese food ,great atmosphere and friendly service  a must stop on the Pittsburgh food trail.

1-Nsw1HnT50VuwbKSdVSYA.text: The atmosphere is very intimate and cozy- it reminded me of fine dining experiences in Manhattan. However our meals were a bit disappointing- the filet mignon burger ordered medium rare was cooked well done and dry, the lamb burger (while a large portion) was overcooked and dry. Overall, the experience didn't match the expense of the restaurant.

3O3Yu4agQwKHANRyyjWRzA.text: Do not understand the hype about this place. My food was really bland and the prices were INSANE! I was in shock how much my experience did not match up with the reviews.

k7JjauXenI-94ptfD0Pc6A.text: Very cute and home-y restaurant with European style meals.  I ordered the bronzino which is a sea bass I believe and it came whole cooked to perfection with a light lemon sauce.    I don't know if this is authentic Portuguese food I have never eaten Portuguese food but my taste buds know what they like!    I read someone's review which said "bland" but I personally believe that if something is of good quality and cooked right then you don't need all the extras to cover up the natural flavors of the meat and vegetables.  Especially fish and meat.  BYOB is a plus***  Great, friendly service!

OAAu-8ncliljShJtZ8YQVg.text: This place is just lovely! When you walk in, it's inviting and cozy. You'd never know it was an old garage. Plus, it's BYOB, so that's always a perk. Let's add in super friendly service, and it's a wine, I mean win.   I had high hopes, especially with how much I loved the ambiance. I love tomato bisque, so I was excited to dive into that for a first course, but it was very strangely thin. When you imagine bisque, you imagine heavy cream used, but I believe it was broth based. I just wasn't digging it.   But then our starter came out, a goat cheese-stuffed puff pastry, and it was divine! Things were looking up! It was a delicious mix of cheese, plus light and airy puff pastry that we gobbled up.   Me and a friend split two main courses; the Butternut Squash Ravioli with Pumpkin Coulis and the lamb burger with fontina and caramelized onions. I love lamb and I love squash, so this was the perfect splitting combo. I was pretty bummed when the lamb burger, while good lamb, didn't give off a lot of flavor. Which was surprising considering it also had caramelized onions, which usually pack a flavorful punch. The butternut squash ravioli also didn't offer the flavors imagines. Mostly it was the sauce that seemed to fall flat with this dish.   There was a sweet ending my friends, this cute little mason jar filled with layers of fresh raspberries, cream and Portuguese cookies was an amazing finish. I only wish everything had been equally as amazing.  I still feel like I'm not done with Cafe Zinho, so hopefully the next visit will be all wines, er wins!
